summary: This document is an email chain from July 25, 2019, discussing the reported incident on July 24, 2019, where Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at MCC New York with a noose around his neck. The emails reveal confusion and conflicting reports about the details of the incident and Epstein's subsequent suicide watch status.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email chain; reported found in his cell with a noose around his neck and placed on suicide watch/observation.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.role: Associate Warden at MCC New York
persons.context: Reported the incident regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the Supervisory Deputy United States Marshal.

persons.name: Supervisory Deputy United States Marshal Southern District of New York
persons.context: Authored the initial incident report that was forwarded in the email chain.

persons.name: SHU Lieutenant
persons.role: Lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit
persons.context: Wrote the first report about the incident, mentioning only redness on Epstein's neck without noting an object.

connections.description: The Associate Warden at MCC New York reported the incident involving Epstein to authorities.
The SHU Lieutenant wrote the initial report on the incident involving Epstein in his cell.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at MCC New York at 0127 hours in a fetal position with a noose around his neck. He was escorted to medical, assessed, and initially placed on suicide watch, then downgraded to suicide observation.

events.title: Email Chain Discussing Incident Details
events.description: An email chain discusses conflicting reports about the Epstein cell incident, specifically whether a noose was reported and the status of his suicide watch.

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at MCC New York on July 24, 2019, at 0127 hours with a noose around his neck.
Conflicting reports existed: the SHU Lieutenant's initial report mentioned only redness on Epstein's neck, while two other responding officers reported seeing an object around his neck.
Epstein was initially placed on suicide watch after the incident but was subsequently downgraded to suicide observation.
Epstein's cell mate reportedly felt threatened, stating Epstein had threatened to kill him.
The incident was under investigation by the Bureau of Prisons at the time of the correspondence.
